title: ZarOptimal
author: ZarOptimal
content: Most people told me, move to monero, move to zephyr protocol, move to ergowhat i did? i sold all my coins and moved to bitcoin when bitcoin was below 26000i was wrong doing this ? notwhy?because of thisevery time you use bitcoin and usdt, first, i move it to a exchange wallet, and i extract only what im going to use, when a criminal tracks your transaction historial through bitcoin explorer, they wont see your cold wallet, they will see a exchange wallet balance ( millions and millions of dollars ) by this way your bitcoin turns anonymous in 99.9% because only the government and exchanges will know your balancewe dont need privacy currencies, we just need to do that and doneunder this way of see it i moved back to bitcoin and in the end i was right, and we are close to be on 100.000 while privacy zk coins are on road to 0as you all can see, privacy currencies are not following bitcoin pumpsthe future is from bitcoinremember before pay on streets first move from your cold storage, to exchange, and from exchange to a fresh wallet, and pay through that way99.9% safe and you wont be trackedexamples: if a place where you pay with bitcoin is intercepted and not only the vendor is watching its computer they can track your balancethink in more examplesmy way solves it, and we dont really will need a privacy currencyprivacy is pointless with this method, only exchanges and govs will see the owner

comments.author: BlackHatCoiner
comments.body: Quote from: ZarOptimal on November 20, 2024, 08:43:48 PMby this way your bitcoin turns anonymous in 99.9% because only the government and exchanges will know your balanceWhile perhaps many people in this world do not mind the government intruding in their financial activities, there are many who do so, and it's usually primarily the government they're trying to hide their money from. It's the same as saying that your bank account is 99.9% anonymous or private, just because "only" the bank and the government knows about it.Quotethe future is from bitcoinSure, but there is apparently a market emerged from actual use of privacy coins. Evidently, people need them. Privacy in bitcoin can be protected with coinjoin, but it'd be foolish to think that it's private otherwise.

comments.author: Stalker22
comments.body: Quote from: ZarOptimal on November 20, 2024, 08:43:48 PMprivacy is pointless with this method, only exchanges and govs will see the ownerLOL! I wouldnt even call this privacy.  The exchanges know where all your coins are coming from, but you got no clue who they might be sharing that info with.  Especially some of those sketchier ones.  Nowadays most big exchanges make you do some kind of KYC stuff and  so really, doing it your way you would probably lose privacy compared to just paying straight from your wallet.  Basically you are giving up actual privacy for for a false sense of privacy.  Sure, it might look on the surface like your wallet is hidden if you use them.  But you are really trusting some other company with all your personal data and  who knows if they will handle it right? Privacy coins, on the other hand, offer true privacy by obscuring the sender and receiver of transactions. Thats a way better way to keep your financial business private.

comments.author: Ever-young
comments.body: If your identity is already known by the government and also by the exchange, where is the privacy? What else are you hiding, and who are you hiding it from?  If you want to remain private, the best way is to hold your coin in a non-custodial wallet. You can hold the large amount on a separate wallet, which could either be a hardware wallet or an open-source wallet that you will be sure of your coins being under your control.  If your fear is about linking your holdings with a public address where you want to make some purchases, that can only happen if you want it to happen. You are not limited to having only one wallet, which means you can fund one particular wallet with a small amount, which you can consider as your spending wallet, and each time a store tries to track how much you hold, there will always be little to nothing in that wallet.

comments.body: You have to coinjoin in order to make your Bitcoin private: https://mempool.space/tx/70aad1d92dd3fc6ddbd802ed20ed155472a5752126a0c3489b56fde6e4cf801cThis coinjoin makes it impossible to determine which inputs belong to each user, which outputs belong to each user, or which inputs belong to the outputs of those users. Participants get complete on chain privacy (for any amounts that are not far greater than the overall liquidity of all the other participants).

comments.author: Darker45
comments.body: You may not need privacy-centered cryptocurrencies or privacy-enhancing processes, but others might need it. So, it isn't really pointless. After all, what you consider privacy might not be privacy to others. What's sufficiently private to you may be insufficient to others. In the first place, exchanges and governments aren't a single individual. Do you know how many people in a single exchange alone have access to your personal information and transaction history? Do you even know how they handle private data? Are you sure they aren't sharing it with others unnecessarily or secretly? Or selling and trading them?

comments.author: Catenaccio
comments.body: Bitcoin is not a private and anonymous blockchain, and you can not have 100% privacy and anonymity with Bitcoin blockchain.You can use Bitcoin full node, Tor, cleverly use your inputs and outputs to increase your privacy and anonymity, but it's never 100% achievable because of Bitcoin design does not provide it.It's complicated for newbies but if you want to have privacy and anonymity, you must learn.Bitcoin privacy guides.

comments.author: ranochigo
comments.body: Bitcoin is pseudonymous by design, whatever you're doing basically means that you are exposing yourself somewhere along the chain. This isn't ideal and probably not something that people are looking to utilize privacy-enhancing coins for. By far, criminals are not going to bother tracing your funds because they don't have enough resources. Governments, or state sponsored actors in that case have considerable resources to do so and can absolutely know everything about you. They are the entity that you should be worried about.

comments.author: SquirrelJulietGarden
comments.body: Some steps guided by Blockchair.com to have privacy with Bitcoin blockchain.Privacy-o-meter for Bitcoin Transactions. You can see their detailed guide below.QuoteGeneral guidelines for sending BTC transactionsBlockchair can not help you improve the privacy of your transactions but here are some basic recommendations on how to stay anonymous on the Bitcoin networkDon't send round numbersDon't send round amounts. Instead of sending 0.1 BTC, send 0.10125Use Bitcoin MixersMixers add an additional layer of privacy to a transaction to avoid exposing user identities.Avoid reusing walletsDon't send your Bitcoin change to the same address you use for sending bitcoins.Avoid including many of your addresses in one transactionAny time you can, try not to send BTC from your various Bitcoin addresses.Avoid using "send everything" optionIf you are withdrawing funds from an exchange, it is okay.If you're moving funds to another wallet, do not transfer the whole amount to another address. It greatly compromises your privacy.You can copy and paste your Bitcoin address on blockchair.com explorer and check your privacy score. Remember to do this check with Tor. You can use another blockchain explorer to check privacy too.Example with one Bitcoin transaction.https://blockchair.com/bitcoin/transaction/0ba639c4ab4a4e5fe7d257f530efe0c79c7273aef8efa2c2a42ff2a4cb5bde4dhttps://blockstream.info/tx/0ba639c4ab4a4e5fe7d257f530efe0c79c7273aef8efa2c2a42ff2a4cb5bde4d

comments.body: If you bought your bitcoin from a KYC institution, there is no way to erase that record of your purchases.All you can do to give yourself on-chain privacy is to use one of the many CoinJoin methods or swap UTXOs with someone else to break the chain of ownership on those UTXOs.Once you buy from a KYC platform, there's no way to undue that to regain your privacy.

comments.author: MarketNeutral
comments.created_time: November 22, 2024, 02:43:46 PMLast edit: November 22, 2024, 07:20:27 PM by MarketNeutral
comments.body: You have to take privacy into your own hands. Monero is ideal, but in terms of Bitcoin, privacy is a nightmare unless you take proactive measures.I never talked to Satoshi, but I'm pretty sure that he didn't intend to create banking 2.0 and its subsequent monetary ecosystem requiring humiliating selfies for KYC laws and approval from banking entities, just to open crypto accounts and withdraw funds. Bitcoin users certainly haven't helped in this regard, as they've chased profits over any remaining cypherpunk, anti-bank ethos, but this is to be expected.The Bitcoin devs, however, have always been in a position to do more. They pay lip service to privacy sometimes, but they've made it clear that they have taken the path of least resistance and abide pretty much any banking regulation, no matter how draconian or unjust, rather than create a privacy-respecting ecosystem outside of the banking system. They could have implemented privacy-centric features into Bitcoin Core if they really wanted to, but that ship sailed long ago. No one expects them to go full Monero, but they've had opportunities (native mweb, native coinjoin, etc) to increase Bitcoin privacy, but they are content to create banking 2.0 instead. They have not supported privacy advocacy within the law. They have not pursued lawful means to circumvent privacy-invasive analytics and regulations.So it's up to you. And you have to learn it on your own.You can always use mixers as explained here: https://bitmixlist.orgLearn how to safely use Tor (and i2p), the Tor Browser, and familiarize yourself with using onion links. For example, here's the onion version of the bitmixlist.org site: http://kmzvdt7443fqisu27xw3saxv7rn2pmgx33zd2cy54ev2mbba2xjoziqd.onionTails OS, which has a Bitcoin Electrum client built in, routes all traffic through Tor (but it won't help you if you're dumb).For any cryptocurrencies you use, its best to run your own node if possible.You can use exchanges and services that don't require AML / KYC information: https://kycnot.meAlso keep in mind that chain analytics isn't just about IP addresses, but also patterns like timing, amounts, and other correlating data.And as most users know, avoid address re-use whenever possible.Also keep in mind that you need to be cautious on this forum, too. It's been hacked before, with user names and password exposed, and high-profile members both in the past (such as Gavin Andresen @gavinandresen ) and present ( forum admin Michael Marquardt @theymos ) have cooperated with law enforcement agencies that actively profile users and engage in blockchain analysis. There are also a lot of shady dealings that newer users might not know about, such as infamous donation scam with Slickage Studios that theymos himself participated in, scamming thousands of Bitcoins from unsuspecting forum members. I know I'm mentioning security in terms of privacy, but there's a lot of overlap between the two. Further, it's worth considering that some accounts change hands easily, and you need to be extraordinarily careful whom you trust. Remember, above all else: not your keys, not your coins.Edit: Bisq is great for exchanging Bitcoin in a decentralized way without the burden of AML/KYC getting in the way.
